storyContent.tagHTML: Indra's Praise and the Demigods' Doubts

One day, during an assembly of demigods, Indra, the king of heavenly gods, praised the bravery and mercifulness of King Meghrath on Earth. He mentioned that King Meghrath would not hesitate to give up his own life to protect those who came to him for shelter.

Two demigods doubted Indra’s statement, so Indra asked them to go to Earth and see for themselves. Since they could not appear on Earth in their heavenly forms, one of them decided to take the form of a pigeon, and the other took the form of a hawk. The demigods, due to their miraculous power, can assume any form they desire and can reach anywhere in the world in a split second.
The Test Begins: Pigeon Seeks Refuge

Down on Earth, King Meghrath was sitting in his court surrounded by his courtiers. Suddenly, a pigeon flew in through an open window and started circling the hall. To the King’s surprise, it landed on his lap. It was shaking uncontrollably. The King realized that the pigeon was shaking with fear and had flown into the palace to seek refuge.
The Hawk's Demand

At that very instant, a hawk flew into the king’s court. He said to the King, “This pigeon is my food. Let me have him.” The king was dumbfounded to hear a bird talk, however, he replied, “It is true that this pigeon is your food, but now it is under my shelter. I will not give you this pigeon, but I can give you other food.” He ordered his servants to bring a basket of fruits and vegetables. However, the hawk said, “I am not a human being, and I am not a vegetarian. I need meat for my food.”
The King's Sacrifice

The king said, “Let me give you my own flesh instead of this pigeon’s flesh.” Upon hearing this, one of the courtiers said, “Your Majesty, why should you give your own flesh? Let’s get meat from a butcher.” The king replied, “No, because the butcher will have to kill another animal in order to supply us the meat. This pigeon has sought refuge, and it is my duty to protect it. At the same time, it is also my duty to see that no one else is harmed in the process. Therefore, I will give my own flesh to the hawk.”

With these words, he took out his knife and cut off a piece of flesh from his thigh and offered that to the hawk. The whole court was stunned, however, the hawk said to the king, “Oh king, I want the same amount of flesh as the pigeon.” The King ordered for a weighing scale to be brought to the court. He put the pigeon on one side and a piece of his own flesh on the other and kept adding more and more of his flesh on the scale, but it was not enough.

Finally, the king got ready to put his whole body on the scale. The court was stunned that the king was giving up his own life for an insignificant bird. Nevertheless, the king considered his duty to protect the bird to be above everything else. He sat on the scale on the side opposite the pigeon, closed his eyes, and began meditating.
The Revelation and Divine Praise

As soon as the king began meditating, the pigeon and the hawk assumed their original divine forms. Both demigods bowed to the king and said, “Oh great king! You are blessed. You deserve all the praise given by Lord Indra. We are convinced that you are a brave and merciful king.”
With these words, they praised and saluted the king again and left. The whole court resounded with cheers of joy, “Long live King Meghrath”.
King Meghrath's Future as a Tirthankar
Later, the soul of King Meghrath became the sixteenth Tirthankar, Bhagawän Shäntinäth.
Moral

This story teaches us that it is the chief duty of everyone to protect and help those who are less fortunate. A merciful person is someone who is not only influenced by seeing the misery and suffering of others but goes a step further and attempts to alleviate the pain. He gives financial aid to those who are poor and gives food to those who are hungry and needy. A merciful person would not harm others to save his/her own life, but on the contrary, would sacrifice his/her own life to save the lives of the others.
Highlights

• Demigods test King Meghrath, who is ready to give up his life to save another’s
• King Meghrath’s soul later becomes Shäntinäth Bhagawän (16th Tirthankar)

events.title: Indra's Praise
events.description: Indra, king of heavenly gods, praises King Meghrath's bravery and mercifulness, stating he would give his life to protect refugees.

events.title: Demigods' Doubt and Plan
events.description: Two demigods doubt Indra's praise and decide to test King Meghrath by taking the forms of a pigeon and a hawk.

events.title: Pigeon Seeks Refuge
events.description: A pigeon (a demigod in disguise) flies into King Meghrath's court and lands on his lap, seeking refuge.

events.title: Hawk's Arrival and Demand
events.description: A hawk (a demigod in disguise) arrives and demands the pigeon as its food.

events.title: King's Offer of Alternative Food
events.description: King Meghrath offers the hawk fruits and vegetables, which the hawk refuses as it needs meat.

events.title: King Offers His Own Flesh
events.description: Refusing to harm another animal, King Meghrath offers his own flesh to the hawk.

events.title: The Weighing Scale
events.description: The hawk demands flesh equal to the pigeon's weight. King Meghrath cuts flesh from his thigh, but it's insufficient on the scale.

events.title: Ultimate Sacrifice Offered
events.description: King Meghrath prepares to offer his whole body, sits on the scale, and begins meditating.

events.title: Divine Forms Revealed
events.description: As King Meghrath meditates, the pigeon and hawk assume their original divine forms.

events.title: Demigods' Praise
events.description: The demigods bow to King Meghrath, acknowledging his bravery and mercy, confirming Indra's words.

events.title: Path to Tirthankarhood

charactersData.name: King Meghrath
charactersData.description: A brave and exceptionally merciful king on Earth, who was willing to sacrifice his own life to protect a pigeon that sought his refuge. His soul later became Bhagawän Shäntinäth.

charactersData.name: Indra
charactersData.description: The king of heavenly gods, who praised King Meghrath's virtues in an assembly of demigods.

charactersData.name: Two Demigods
charactersData.description: Heavenly beings who doubted Indra's praise of King Meghrath and decided to test him by taking the forms of a pigeon and a hawk.

charactersData.name: Pigeon (Demigod in disguise)
charactersData.description: The form taken by one of the demigods to test King Meghrath by seeking his shelter.

charactersData.name: Hawk (Demigod in disguise)
charactersData.description: The form taken by the other demigod to test King Meghrath by demanding the pigeon as its prey.

charactersData.name: Bhagawän Shäntinäth
charactersData.description: The sixteenth Tirthankar, who was the future incarnation of King Meghrath's soul.

quizData.question: Who praised King Meghrath's mercifulness in the assembly of demigods?
quizData.answer: Indra, the king of heavenly gods.

quizData.question: Why did two demigods decide to test King Meghrath?
quizData.answer: They doubted Indra’s statement about King Meghrath's willingness to sacrifice his life for those seeking shelter.

quizData.question: What forms did the two demigods take to test King Meghrath?
quizData.answer: One took the form of a pigeon, and the other took the form of a hawk.

quizData.question: Where did the pigeon land when it sought refuge from King Meghrath?
What did the hawk demand from King Meghrath?
quizData.answer: The pigeon, claiming it as its food.

quizData.question: What was King Meghrath's reason for not getting meat from a butcher for the hawk?
quizData.answer: He did not want another animal to be killed to supply the meat.

quizData.question: What did King Meghrath offer the hawk after it refused fruits and vegetables?
What condition did the hawk place when King Meghrath offered his flesh?
quizData.answer: The hawk wanted the same amount of flesh as the pigeon's weight.

quizData.question: What did King Meghrath do when pieces of his flesh were not enough to equal the pigeon's weight on the scale?
quizData.answer: He prepared to put his whole body on the scale and began meditating.

quizData.question: What happened immediately after King Meghrath sat on the scale and began meditating?
quizData.answer: The pigeon and the hawk assumed their original divine forms as demigods.

quizData.question: What did the demigods declare after revealing their true forms?
quizData.answer: They declared King Meghrath blessed, brave, and merciful, confirming Indra's praise.

quizData.question: Who did the soul of King Meghrath later become?
What is the primary moral of the story of King Meghrath?
quizData.answer: It is the chief duty of everyone to protect and help those who are less fortunate, even if it requires personal sacrifice.

children.name: Context: Indra's Praise of Meghrath's Mercy
Conflict: Demigods' Skepticism Leads to a Test
Setup: Pigeon (Demigod) seeks refuge, Hawk (Demigod) pursues.
Meghrath's Stand: Prioritizes protection and non-violence.
Ultimate Offer: Entire body to match pigeon's weight
Climax: Meghrath meditates, ready for death.
Revelation: Pigeon and Hawk revert to Demigod forms.
Validation: Meghrath's supreme compassion is affirmed.
Karmic Fruit: Soul becomes Bhagawän Shäntinäth (16th Tirthankar).
Core Lesson: The paramount duty to protect the vulnerable, even at the cost of one's own life.
